data.title: WB Timeline
data.meta_description: 1903 Warner brothers entered film business as traveling exhibitors in Ohio and Pennsylvania Warner brothers opened their first theater, the Cascade in New Castle, Pennsylvania (1903?) 1904 Warner brothers founded the Duquesne Amusement & Supply Company in Pittsburgh to distribute films. 1907 Warner brothers operating Cascade Theatre in New Castle, Pennsylvania. 1908 Warner brothers had…
data.text:
1903

Warner brothers entered film business as traveling exhibitors in Ohio and Pennsylvania

Warner brothers opened their first theater, the Cascade in New Castle, Pennsylvania (1903?)

1904

Warner brothers founded the Duquesne Amusement & Supply Company in Pittsburgh to distribute films.

1907

Warner brothers operating Cascade Theatre in New Castle, Pennsylvania.

1908

Warner brothers had acquired 200 film titles, distributing throughout western Pennsylvania as the Duquesne Film Exchange, later opening exchanges in Norfolka, Virginia and Atlanta, Georgia. Warner Brothers subsequently moved to California to start producing films, establishing small production base at 18th St. and Main St. in Culver City, California. [much of this language taken from WB Company History site]

1918

My Four Years in Germany

1918

Warner Bros. West Coast Studios established at 5842 Sunset Blvd.

4/4/1923

Warner brothers company formerly incorporated as Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc.

1924

Rin Tin Tin

The Marriage Circle (1924)

1925

Meetings with Western Electric, Bell Laboratories regarding “talking pictures.” Installed new sound equipment in newly acquired Vitagraph Studios in Brooklyn.

Establishing KFWB radio station in Los Angeles

1926

8/6/1926

Don Juan premiere at Warners’ Theatre in New York

1927

10/6/1927

The Jazz Singer

1928

Warners purchased Stanley Corporation of America’s theater chain, including one-third ownership of First National Pictures. Later purchased the rest of First National Pictures, acquiring Burbank studio facilities.

1929

First National releases first film with Warner Bros., Noah’s Ark.

Warner Bros. bought St. Louis-based theater chain Skouras Brothers. Spyros Skouras became general manager of teh Warner Brothers Theater Circuit in America.

1930

April 1930

Harry Warner acqauired Brunswick Records, established Warner Bros. Music.

11/5/1930

Disraeli nominated for Best Picture at 3rd Academy Awards

1932

11/18/1932

Five Star Final nominated for Best Picture at 5th Academy Awards.

1933

Daryl Zanuck leaves Warner Bros.

February 1933

Warner Bros. produced 42nd Street

1934

Studio fire at Burbank studio

Harry Warner officially purchased Teddington Studios in London, England.

3/16/1934

42nd Street nominated for Best Picture at 6th Academy Awards

1935

Harry Warner and six other movie studios indicted for conspiracy to violate the Sherman Antitrust Act, in attempt to gain a monopoly over St. Louis movie theaters. In 1935, Harry Warner was put on trial. After mistrial, Harry Warner sold the company’s movie theaters.

1930s

The Petrified Forest; Little Caesar; The Public Enemy; I Am a Fugitive from a Chain Gang; Black Legion; Black Fury; They Won’t Forget; A Midsummer Night’s Dream; 42nd Street; Errol Flynn swashbucklers; filmed biographies (Benjamin Disareli, Louis Pasteur, Benito Juarez, Emile Zola); Looney Tunes and Merrie Melodies shorts

1938

3/10/1938

First Warner Bros. Best Picture winner, The Life of Emile Zola at 10th Academy Awards

1940s

The Maltese Falcon; Sergeant York; Kings Row; Yankee Doodle Dandy; Casablanca

1942

11/26/1942

Premiere of Casablanca at Hollywood Theatre

1943

1/23/1943

General release of Casablanca

1944

3/2/1944

Warner Bros. wins Best Picture Oscar for Casablanca

1955

Warner Bros. Television began

1956

June 1956

Allied Artists Productions Corp. (a.a.p.) acquired pre-1950 Warner Bros. Pictures library for $21 million, Lou Chelser’s PRM, Inc. closed the purchase, with a.a.p. and its theatrical subsidiary Dominant Pictures handling distribution sales. Purchased rights to all features produced and distributed by Warner Bros. prior to 1950 (Warner Bros. retained rights to two 1949 films it only distributed), and also included Chain Lightning (produced 1949, released 1950). It also included live-action short subjects released prior to September 1, 1948. The cartoon library included every color Looney Tunes and Merrie Melodies short released prior to August 1, 1948, and all of the Merrie Melodies produced by Harman-Ising Pictures from 1931 to 1933, except Lady, Play Your Mandolin! (1931). The remaining black-and-white Merrie Melodies made from 1933-1934 and the black-and-white Looney Tunes were already sold to Sunset Productions. Former Warner cartoon director Bob Clampett was hired to catalogue the Warner cartoon library.

[language from Wikipedia]

1958

United Artists Associated acquired by United Artists, renamed United Artists Associated (u.a.a.).

Auntie Mame

July 1958

Harry Warner died

1962

The Music Man

1963

America America

1964

My Fair Lady

1965

4/5/1965

My Fair Lady wins Best Picture at 37th Academy Awards, additional awards.

1966

Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?

1967

Bonnie and Clyde

Jack Warner sold Warner Bros. Pictures to Elliot Hyman and Ken Hyman, renamed Warner Bros. – Seven Arts.

April 1967

Albert Warner died.

1969

November 1969

Steve Ross and Kinney Corporation purchased Warner Bros.-Seven Arts, renamed Warner Communications, Inc.

1978

Jack Warner died

1981

MGM purchased United Artists (along with a.a.p. library) from Transamerica Corpration and became MGM/UA Entertainment Co.

1986

Turner Broadcasting System (via Turner Entertainment Co.) took over the MGM/UA library after Ted Turner’s short-lived acquisition of MGM/UA. Turner sold back the MGM/UA production unit, he kept the MGM library, including select portions of the a.a.p library (limited to Warner Bros. films and the Popeye cartoons). Turner Entertainment Co. founded on 8/4/1986.

1990

merger of Warner Communications, Inc. and Time, Inc. to form Time Warner, Inc.

1994

4/14/1994

Tuner Classic Movies (TCM) launched by Turner Entertainment Co.

1996

10/10/1996

Time, Inc. bought Turner Entertainment Co. in 1996. Turner retains the copyrights to the former a.a.p. properties while Warner handles distribution.

1999

Home video rights to MGM/UA library transferred to Warner Home Video.

2009

Warner Home Video introduced Warner Archive Collection. DVD-on-demand service.

2014

July 2014

Warner Archive Collection launched Warner Archive Instant.

Warner Bros. Entertainment Company History [http://www.warnerbros.com/studio/about-studio/company-history]
